curam.util.type
Class FrequencyPattern

java.lang.Object
  curam.util.type.FrequencyPattern
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable
public final class FrequencyPattern
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable

A frequency pattern is a flexible way of defining the frequency with which an event recurs. Once the pattern is defined, you can use it to determine dates on which an event occurs before or after a specified date, or between a range of dates.

A frequency pattern consists of four fields. The pattern type field is one of daily, weekly, monthly, or yearly. The remaining fields -- interval, day of week, and day of month-- are interpreted differently depending on the pattern type. Below, we describe the allowable values for the day of week and day of month fields, and then explain how they work with each of the pattern types.

The day of week field is a set, which may contain any combination of days of the week from Monday to Sunday. Special values for the day of week field indicate each day (Monday to Sunday), weekend days (Saturday, Sunday), or week days (Monday to Friday).

The day of month field is a day number from 1 to 31. Special values for the day of month field are first, second, third, fourth and last. These special values in combination with a day of week indicate a particular occurrence of a week day within a month, for instance "the first Friday".

For daily patterns the interval field indicates how often the pattern recurs. The day of month field is ignored. The day of week field can be set to any of its allowable values. The simplest daily patterns have a day of week value of each day. The interval then simply defines the number of days between recurrences. If the day of week field contains any other set of days, then the interval is used to count days that are contained in the set. For example, if the set contains Monday+Wednesday+Friday, and the interval is 4, then the first occurrence after Sunday 16-Jun-2002 is Monday 24-Jun-2002 -- the fourth day in the set after the start date.

For weekly patterns the interval field indicates how often (in weeks) the pattern recurs. If the day of week field is not set, then the pattern simply recurs every nth week, where n is the interval. If the day of week field is set, then the result is computed as if no day of week was set, and then rolled forward to the next matching day of week.

For monthly patterns the interval field indicates how often (in months) the pattern recurs. If the day of month field is set to a value between 1 and 31, then the pattern recurs on the specified day of each nth month, where n is the interval. If, for any given month in which the pattern recurs, the day of month value is greater than the number of days in the month, then the pattern recurs on the last day of the month. If no day of month is specified, then the day of month is taken to be the same day as the start date (you always specify a start date when requesting a next occurrence). If the day of month is set to one of the special values -- first, second, third, fourth and last-- then the day of week field is used to determine the result. For instance, a day of month value of third in combination with a day of week of "Friday" and an interval of 2 would indicate the "third Friday" of every second month.

For bi-monthly patterns the pattern specifies two events which occur every month. Two day of month fields are required so the first two characters of the interval field are used to store the second day of month value. (The interval field is redundant since by definition the pattern occurs twice per month.) The day of month fields must both be either a numeric value between 1 and 31 or one of the the special values -- first, second, third, fourth and last. For example it is possible to specify bi-monthly patterns of the form "Day 14 and 30 of every month." and "The first and last Saturday of every month.". However it is not possible to specify a bi-monthly pattern of "Day 14 and the last Saturday of every month" because this is actually two distinct patterns and this information cannot be stored within a single frequency pattern. For bi-monthly patterns where the two components overlap, only one occurrence is returned. For example in some months the bi-monthly pattern "The fourth and last Friday of every month" will correspond to one day, in other months it will correspond to two different days. In the case where it corresponds to a single day, only one occurrence is returned. Similarly it is possible - although misleading - to specify a bi-monthly pattern where each of the two components are identical. In this case the result is the same as a one-monthly pattern. For example the bi-monthly pattern "The first and first day of every month" will behave the same as the monthly pattern "The first day of every month".

Finally, for yearly patterns, the interval field is treated as a month number (1 for January, 12 for December). The day of week field and day of month field are used as for monthly patterns. The pattern recurs each year on the specified day of the specified month.

kZeroFrequencyPattern

public static final FrequencyPattern kEachWeekdayPattern

kDailyPattern

public static final FrequencyPattern kDailyPattern
A daily pattern for each day.

kStartDayEachWeekPattern

public static final FrequencyPattern kStartDayEachWeekPattern
A weekly pattern recurring on a specified day in each week. The day used with this pattern is the day of the week corresponding to the date on which the pattern is applied. For example this pattern applied to Wednesday 14th January will result in Wednesday the 21st January.

kFirstDayOfMonthPattern

public static final FrequencyPattern kFirstDayOfMonthPattern
A monthly pattern for the first day in each month.

Constructor Detail

FrequencyPattern

public FrequencyPattern()
Default Constructor.

FrequencyPattern

public FrequencyPattern(java.lang.String pattern)
                 throws AppRuntimeException
Construct a Frequency Pattern from a string.

Parameters:
pattern - The String representing the FrequencyPattern should be in the following format:
  • Character 1: patternType as a single digit
    • 0 : Daily
    • 1 : Weekly
    • 2 : Monthly
    • 3 : Yearly
    • 4 : Bi-monthly
  • Characters 2-4: interval as a three-digit number or, for bi-monthly patterns, the second dayOfMonth as a two-digit number followed by zero.
  • Characters 5-7: dayOfWeekMask as a three-digit number
    • 1 : Monday
    • 2 : Tuesday
    • 4 : Wednesday
    • 8 : Thursday
    • 16 : Friday
    • 32 : Saturday
    • 64 : Sunday
    • 201: `Eachday`
    • 202: Weekday
    • 203: `Weekendday`
  • Characters 8-9: dayOfMonth as a two-digit number
    • 32 : first
    • 33 : second
    • 34 : third
    • 35 : fourth
    • 36 : last
All fields are zero-padded on the left.
Throws:
AppRuntimeException - RUN_ID_FREQUENCY_CONVERSION - if FrequencyPattern cannot be converted from String

public boolean isZeroPattern()
Check if the pattern is the default (a non-recurring daily pattern where the interval is zero and patternType is daily).

Returns:

toHumanReadableString

public java.lang.String toHumanReadableString()
Gets an English human readable string which describes the frequency pattern for debug purposes. NB the string returned by this method is not localisable and should not be displayed to clients of the application, nor included in any client-visible reports/emails/etc generated by the application.

Returns:
A human readable version of the Frequency Pattern - in the English language.
